"Clinton done well." No, no, no a thousand times no.

In order to get reappointed to the Federal Reserve he slashed interest 
rates and flooded the economy with cheap credit. The Clinton administration 
had been making public comments before the Fed (and Greenspan's potential 
reappointment!) started easing.

The result was a tech/credit bubble. Billy Boy got re-elected. Greenspan 
got reappointed. And the tech bubble resulted in misallocation of labor and 
material resources. There was an ephemeral prosperity (just like housing 
bubble that Fed blew up!) for awhile. Tax revenues soared, which is why 
deficits fell. But then the phony bubble popped and with it all the phony 
increased tax revenue.

Moreover, if the govt. included all the things it ludicrously calls 
"off-balance sheet debt" the "surpluses" during the Clinton years turn into 
deficits.

The govt. doesn't count unfunded liabilities for entitlement programs. It 
does not even adhere to standard accounting practice that requires all 
future obligations to be included on a balance sheet. All publicly traded 
companies must adhere to those standard accounting practices, but the govt. 
doesn't hold itself to those rules. If it did, all reported deficits are 
much higher and the reported surpluses of the latter Clinton years turn 
into deficits.

 The president signs the budget after he has submitted his proposal to

process for establishing a coherent budget. When newly elected President 
Richard Nixon began to refuse to spend funds that the Congress had 
allocated, Congress adopted a more formal means by which to challenge him.

Office (CBO) and directed more control of the budget to it and away from 
the President's Office of Management and Budget (OMB). The Act passed 
easily while the administration was embroiled in the Watergate scandal and 
unwilling to provoke Congress.[3

Read this carefully: The REPORTED deficits and debt are an effing joke! The 
annual deficits and total debt number does not include Freddie/Fannie debt 
(in trillions!) and it does not include S.S./Medicare/Medicaid unfunded 
liabilities, which are in the tens of trillions.

Standard accounting rules call for businesses to report all future 
obligations on their balance sheet. The govt. doesn't abide by that same 
rules. It places tens of trillions of debt off-balance sheet.

Moreover, the Federal Reserve is monetizing the debt and annual deficits! 
It's purchasing $45 billion per month of treasuries on the secondary 
market. That means interest payment on the debt are artificially low. The 
Fed can't keep those rates low forever. They've already caused commodity 
prices to soar, bubbles and an increased concentration of wealth. And the 
CPI is not capturing a lot of the inflation.

At some point the Fed is going to have to turn the monetary spigot off or 
risk a run on the dollar. Then interest rates will go back to historic 
norms or, more likely, even higher given low savings rate of Americans. At 
that point the reported annual deficits (even with all of the tens of 
trillions of debt off-balance sheet not included) will go well over a 
trillion per year. The federal government will not be able to even service 
the interest on the debt when that day comes.

the tests. Nothing more. That doesn't sound like a good thing personally. 
The whole point of learning, is to apply what you learn in real life/what 
you'd like to do in the future. But with this, it's making it seem like, 
you learn to get a good grade. You learn to get a job. You learn to get 
paid more in life. FUCK that. Education is not about money or grades. 
Education is about learning about the world and exploring it. Not grades or 
GPA. When the fuck has education been about money? Excluding accounting. 
They're special, because the whole thing is about counting money.....

I do not believe that anyone with motivation will find what they need to 
succeed. If that was true the american dream would still be a blazing. But 
I do not believe it's still alive and well. Maybe alive, but well? I don't 
think so. The best I can think of, is student loans. Ya we can go to school 
and earn a degree. But the question is, is it worth it. A large chuck of 
people don't work in the field of their degree, so what's the point of that 
degree? At least when I finish school, I'll know what the point of my 
degree was. To learn more about something I love. If I find something in 
the field, awesome. If I don't, well I was expecting it.

In conclusion, your view is very different from mine. Because your school 
clearly is better than mine was...I do want more funding for high schools, 
but not all high schools. Just the ones that need it. Where I want more 
funding for everyone is college, because FUCK student loans. The economy in 
the US is changing. It's shifting to one that requires degrees. Because 
we're shipping a lot of work overseas. So we can only keep certain jobs 
here in the states. Service jobs will never leave the states. But aside 
from that, a lot of it is up for grabs. So it becomes an international 
fight for a position at times.

In the end, I think you just lived in a nicer place than me, or maybe your 
school has better people working there. I don't know, but your school 
sounds better off than mine was.

welfare-warfare-bureaucratic state. It's not a D or R thing.

comments.text:
The deficit is the amount of debt the the government is borrowing each 
year, that gets added to the total debt. A surplus means the government is 
getting more money than it's spending, meaning that the government can 
begin to pay off it's debt.
comments.author: Rob McCune

comments.text:
which means, that even though the debt have increased, the rate in which it 
has to paid back might have been reduced, which means you can have better 
management of finances, if obama manages to turn the deficit into a  huge

money and pay back in bulk the money that has been borrowed. But before the

comments.author: akshay singh

comments.text:
here's a better explanation, debt is money that has been borrowed, while 
deficit/ surplus is the amount of money you spend in relation to your 
income. let's say you have $1000 wage in a week, but your weekly spending 
is $2000, then you have a deficit of $1000. but if your spending in a week 
is only $500, then you have a surplus of $500. but let's say you want a new 
house, your wages alone will not be able to pay for the house you want, so 
you borrow money that's debt which is will then have to be paid back let's 
say $150 per week in your agreement with the bank, that $150 will then add 
to your weekly spending, if you have a $1000 per week and your normal 
weekly spending is $1000, add the 150 then you have a deficit of $150. You 
then need to think of a new way to reduce your deficit by cutting you're 
other spending, say your weekly salon that costs $200. then you're back on 
a surplus of $50, but you're debt still stands until it's paid back in 
full.
comments.author: akshay singh

comments.text:
deficit and surplus is like cash flow,deficit is you're losing money by 
spending and not gaining, you spending rate is more than your saving rate. 
Surplus is when you still have money whilst you're spending money to keeps 
running. If you have a large deficit, then you need to borrow money to 
balance it out, to break-even so to speak. I don't know how to explain it 
clearer.For example, you start a company, you need to borrow some 
money,that's debt. if you're company is making a positive cash flow whilst 
spending loads of money, that surplus, you have money in your pockets to 
spare, but if you're company is not gaining money, a negative cash flow, 
that's deficit, you need to borrow more money just to balance it. but to be 
clear, negative and positive cash flow is not the same as profit/loss. 
before you can tackle the debt sufficiently, you need to reduce the 
spending rate, and bring it to a surplus, then you would money to back the 
debt. That's the way i understand it.hope it helps :)

comments.text:
+bctopper There are two things you aren't considering.  First is the 
counterbalance to debt interest: inflation.  If the rate of inflation 
exceeds the rate of interest, the actual value of the debt decreases over 
time.  This is important because that's the case for a considerable amount 
of the US federal debt; our government is effectively being paid to go into 
debt.
The second thing that you're not considering is how to get out of debt. 
 Simply put, it's surplus that does this.  Decreasing the deficit is in 
effect progress towards a surplus.  Therefore, if you're concerned about 
debt, you should support lowering the deficit.  This has been brought to 
your attention already in this thread, but you haven't seemed to really 
grasp it.

comments.text:
+bctopper Look at my comment again. The only thing different in my examples 
was the DEFICIT. One stayed at a constant $100, while the other dropped a 
single dollar per year. The deficit is the independent variable, while the 
debt is the dependent variable.
The surplus would mean that we could mitigate how much the debt increases 
by beginning to pay off the loans.
For example, if you had $100 in debt with a 10% interest on it, the next 
year you would owe $110. The year after that, you would owe $121. The year 
after that, you would then owe $133.10. In the fourth year, you would owe 
$147.41. At the fifth year, you would owe $161.05 in debt. If you had paid 
$5 of the debt off each year instead, you would owe $127.47. That's $33.64 
in difference.
comments.author: ShadowhoofUma

comments.text:
+ShadowhoofUma debt doesn't stay constant. There is interest raking up on

So even if there is a surplus, the govt has to cover the interest as well 
as the existing debt, and with the amount of debt we currently have, there 
is hundreds of millions just in interest adding to the debt every year.
comments.author: bctopper

comments.text:
+bctopper Lower deficit means less is added each year. It also means that 
we are getting closer to a surplus, which can then be used to pay off our 
debt.

ex: if we start off with a $100 debt, and have $100 dollars in deficit each 
year for five years with 10% interest. our total debt would be $832.61. If 
the deficit went down by $1 each year (99, 98, 97, 96, 95), the total debt 
would be $813.75.
